intro: Lappula redowskii var. texana, commonly known as Texas lappula, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States. It belongs to the family Chenopodiaceae and is characterized by its small, yellowish-green flowers and hairy stems. The plant typically grows in dry, sandy soils and is adapted to arid environments. Its leaves are alternate and often covered in fine hairs, which help reduce water loss. The species is of interest in botanical studies due to its unique adaptations to harsh climates.
